President Trump: s tweet: President Donald Trump called out New York on Twitter, asserting that the state did not fight against the provision in the 2017 tax law that limited deductions of state and local taxes to $10,000. This tweet serves as the initial claim made by Trump.
Rep: Nita Lowey's response: Rep. Nita Lowey, a Democrat representing Rockland County and part of Westchester County, immediately challenged Trump's claim. She tweeted that New York did fight against the Republican elimination of the SALT deduction and criticized Trump for not joining her in convincing members of his own party to reverse their decision.
Governor Cuomo: s reaction: Governor Cuomo of New York strongly disagreed with Trump's claim and stated that he had been fighting against the SALT cap provision since it was proposed in 2017. He called it an assault on New York and criticized Trump for running away from his own policy.
Efforts by Governor Cuomo and other gove: Governor Cuomo launched a campaign against the SALT provision using legal and legislative tools. He even met with Trump at the White House to discuss changes to the cap and announced that he had enlisted other governors in the effort to repeal the SALT provision. This demonstrates the active fight against the provision by New York and other states.
